<p>The <b>City of Durango</b> is a <a href="/wiki/Colorado_municipalities#Home_Rule_Municipality" title="Colorado municipalities" class="mw-redirect">Home Rule Municipality</a> that is the <a href="/wiki/County_seat" title="County seat">county seat</a> and the most populous city of <a href="/wiki/La_Plata_County,_Colorado" title="La Plata County, Colorado">La Plata County</a>, <a href="/wiki/Colorado" title="Colorado">Colorado</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GR6_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GR6-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau" title="United States Census Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a> reported a population of 16,887 in the <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Census" title="2010 United States Census">2010 census</a>.</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Durango,_Colorado&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The town was organized in September 1881 by the <a href="/wiki/Denver_and_Rio_Grande_Railroad" title="Denver and Rio Grande Railroad" class="mw-redirect">Denver and Rio Grande Railroad</a> (D&amp;RG) to serve the San Juan mining district. The D&amp;RG chose a site south of Animas City for its depot after Animas City refused to pay a dowry<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (March 2013)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> to the D&amp;RG. The city is named after <a href="/wiki/Durango,_Durango" title="Durango, Durango">Durango, Mexico</a>, which was named after <a href="/wiki/Durango,_Spain" title="Durango, Spain" class="mw-redirect">Durango, Spain</a>. The word Durango originates from the <a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">Basque</a> word "Urango" meaning "water town".</p>
<p>Area archaeological sites on the State and National historical registers include:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Darkmold_Site" title="Darkmold Site" class="mw-redirect">Darkmold Site</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Basketmaker_culture" title="Basketmaker culture">Basketmaker culture</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Durango_Rock_Shelters_Archeology_Site" title="Durango Rock Shelters Archeology Site">Durango Rock Shelters Archeology Site</a>, a Basketmaker and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Pueblo_People" title="Ancient Pueblo People" class="mw-redirect">Pueblo</a> culture</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Spring_Creek_Archeological_District" title="Spring Creek Archeological District" class="mw-redirect">Spring Creek Archeological District</a> (near Bayfield), another Basketmaker and Pueblo site</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Talus_Village" title="Talus Village" class="mw-redirect">Talus Village</a>, a Basketmaker site</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Durango,_Colorado&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Geography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Durango is located at <span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Durango%2C_Colorado&amp;params=37_16_N_107_52_W_type:city"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">37°„16°‰N</span> <span class="longitude">107°„52°‰W</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">? / ?</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">37.267°„N 107.867°„W</span><span style="display:none">? / <span class="geo">37.267; -107.867</span></span></span></a></span> at an elevation of 1988 metres (6512&#160;feet). According to the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau" title="United States Census Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a>, the city has a total area of 6.8 square miles (18&#160;km<sup>2</sup>).</p>

<p>As of the <a href="/wiki/Census" title="Census">census</a><sup id="cite_ref-GR2_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GR2-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> of 2000, there were 13,922 people, 5,492 households, and 2,603 families residing in the city. The <a href="/wiki/Population_density" title="Population density">population density</a> was 2,052.4 people per square mile (792.8/km2). There were 5,819 housing units at an average density of 857.8 per square mile (331.4/km2). The racial makeup of the city was 86.84% <a href="/wiki/White_(U.S._Census)" title="White (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">White</a>, .5% <a href="/wiki/African_American_(U.S._Census)" title="African American (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">African American</a>, 5.51% <a href="/wiki/Native_American_(U.S._Census)" title="Native American (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Native American</a>, 0.74% <a href="/wiki/Asian_(U.S._Census)" title="Asian (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Asian</a>, 0.11% <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Islander_(U.S._Census)" title="Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Pacific Islander</a>, 4.12% from <a href="/wiki/Race_(United_States_Census)" title="Race (United States Census)" class="mw-redirect">other races</a>, and 2.17% from two or more races. <a href="/wiki/Hispanic_(U.S._Census)" title="Hispanic (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Hispanic</a> or <a href="/wiki/Latino_(U.S._Census)" title="Latino (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Latino</a> of any race were 10.31% of the population.</p>
<p>There were 5,492 households out of which 22.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 34.2% were <a href="/wiki/Marriage" title="Marriage">married couples</a> living together, 9.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 52.6% were non-families. 31.8% of all households were made up of individuals and 9.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.23 and the average family size was 2.83.</p>
<p>In the city, 16.6% of residents are under the age of 18, 26.1% from 18 to 24, 27.2% from 25 to 44, 19.4% from 45 to 64, and 10.7% who are 65 years of age or older. The median age is 29 years. For every 100 females there are 104.1 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there are 103.8 males.</p>
<p>The median income for a household in the city is $34,892, and the median income for a family is $50,814. Males have a median income of $31,812 versus $25,022 for females. The <a href="/wiki/Per_capita_income" title="Per capita income">per capita income</a> for the city is $19,352. 17.2% of the population and 7.3% of families live below the <a href="/wiki/Poverty_line" title="Poverty line" class="mw-redirect">poverty line</a>. 11.2% of those younger than 18 and 8.9% of those 65 and older live below the poverty line.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Arts_and_Culture">Arts and Culture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Durango,_Colorado&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Arts and Culture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Attractions">Attractions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Durango,_Colorado&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Attractions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Animas_River_Valley">Animas River Valley</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Durango,_Colorado&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Animas River Valley">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Durango is nestled in the Animas River Valley surrounded by the <a href="/wiki/San_Juan_Mountains" title="San Juan Mountains">San Juan Mountains</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Animas_River" title="Animas River">Animas River</a>°™El R®™o de las Animas°™runs through downtown and boasts gold medal <a href="/wiki/Fly_fishing" title="Fly fishing">fly fishing</a> waters, and is popular for whitewater rafting, kayaking and canoeing. Durango is also popular for outdoor activities like hiking, mountain biking, road biking, backpacking, rock climbing, hunting, off-roading, year-round fishing, kayaking and golfing.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Durango_Mountain_Resort">Durango Mountain Resort</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Durango,_Colorado&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Durango Mountain Resort">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Durango is near five major ski areas, including <a href="/wiki/Durango_Mountain_Resort" title="Durango Mountain Resort">Purgatory at Durango Mountain Resort</a>, located twenty-five minutes north of downtown. Located thirty-five miles west of Durango is <a href="/wiki/Mesa_Verde_National_Park" title="Mesa Verde National Park">Mesa Verde National Park</a>, a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> World Heritage Site known for its Ancestral Puebloan Cliff Dwellings.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Durango_.26_Silverton_Narrow_Gauge_Railroad">Durango &amp; Silverton Narrow Gauge Railroad</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Durango,_Colorado&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Durango &amp; Silverton Narrow Gauge Railroad">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Durango is most known for the <a href="/wiki/Durango_%26_Silverton_Narrow_Gauge_Railroad" title="Durango &amp; Silverton Narrow Gauge Railroad" class="mw-redirect">Durango &amp; Silverton Narrow Gauge Railroad</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Heritage_railway" title="Heritage railway">heritage railway</a>, which travels from Durango to the historic mining town of <a href="/wiki/Silverton,_Colorado" title="Silverton, Colorado">Silverton, Colorado</a> on <a href="/wiki/Steam_locomotive" title="Steam locomotive">steam-powered trains</a> with rolling stock dating back to the 1920s and before.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Mountain_Bike_World_Championships">Mountain Bike World Championships</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Durango,_Colorado&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Mountain Bike World Championships">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Durango hosted the first-ever <a href="/wiki/Mountain_Bike_World_Championships" title="Mountain Bike World Championships" class="mw-redirect">Mountain Bike World Championships</a> in 1990.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Snowdown_Festival">Snowdown Festival</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Durango,_Colorado&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Snowdown Festival">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Durango is also home to the Snowdown Festival,<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> an event which includes fireworks and a parade. The parade is the centerpiece and usually occurs the last Friday of January or the first Friday of February. Many local businesses hold competitions throughout the week, including a beard growing contest, joke off, hot wing eating contest, beer plunge, and many others. Along with the nearby town of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pagosa_Spring,_Colorado&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pagosa Spring, Colorado (page does not exist)">Pagosa Springs</a>, Durango also hosts the annual <a href="/wiki/Music_in_the_Mountains" title="Music in the Mountains">Music in the Mountains</a> summer music festival, which features performances by many of the world's finest classical musicians.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Main_Avenue">Main Avenue</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Durango,_Colorado&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Main Avenue">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Strater_Hotel.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Strater_Hotel.jpg/220px-Strater_Hotel.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Strater_Hotel.jpg/330px-Strater_Hotel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Strater_Hotel.jpg/440px-Strater_Hotel.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Strater_Hotel.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf20/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
The Strater Hotel in 2010</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Main Avenue cuts through Downtown Durango, home to clothing <a href="/wiki/Boutique" title="Boutique">boutiques</a>, restaurants, <a href="/wiki/Newsagent" title="Newsagent" class="mw-redirect">newsstands</a>, tourist and gift shops, a mall, bars, lounges and other businesses. Many buildings downtown are several stories high and include apartments in the upper levels. Durango's two oldest hotels, The General Palmer and The Strater Hotel, are both at the South end of Main Avenue, one and two blocks away from the train station, respectively. It is also home to many restaurants. Many serve specialty foods including <a href="/wiki/Mexican_cuisine" title="Mexican cuisine">Mexican</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_cuisine" title="Italian cuisine">Italian</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_cuisine" title="French cuisine">French</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thai_cuisine" title="Thai cuisine">Thai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_cuisine" title="Japanese cuisine">Japanese</a> and others serve <a href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_the_United_States" title="Cuisine of the United States">American</a> favorites. Main Avenue is walked by thousands of tourists each week, making it the most popular shopping and relaxing tourist destination in Durango.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Durango,_Colorado&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Infrastructure">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Durango,_Colorado&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Transportation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:D%5ERGW_492_Durango_turntable_8-65x_-_Flickr_-_drewj1946.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/D%5ERGW_492_Durango_turntable_8-65x_-_Flickr_-_drewj1946.jpg/220px-D%5ERGW_492_Durango_turntable_8-65x_-_Flickr_-_drewj1946.jpg" width="220" height="149" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/D%5ERGW_492_Durango_turntable_8-65x_-_Flickr_-_drewj1946.jpg/330px-D%5ERGW_492_Durango_turntable_8-65x_-_Flickr_-_drewj1946.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/D%5ERGW_492_Durango_turntable_8-65x_-_Flickr_-_drewj1946.jpg/440px-D%5ERGW_492_Durango_turntable_8-65x_-_Flickr_-_drewj1946.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:D%5ERGW_492_Durango_turntable_8-65x_-_Flickr_-_drewj1946.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf20/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/DRGW" title="DRGW" class="mw-redirect">DRGW</a> steam locomotive on the Durango <a href="/wiki/Railway_turntable" title="Railway turntable">turntable</a>, 1965.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Durango is served by <a href="/wiki/U.S._Highway_160_(Colorado)" title="U.S. Highway 160 (Colorado)" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Highway 160</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Old_Spanish_Trail_(trade_route)" title="Old Spanish Trail (trade route)">Old Spanish Trail</a>) and <a href="/wiki/U.S._Highway_550_(Colorado)" title="U.S. Highway 550 (Colorado)" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Highway 550</a>. Part of U.S. 550 offers high-speed access (primarily a 4-lane, divided highway) to <a href="/wiki/Albuquerque,_New_Mexico" title="Albuquerque, New Mexico">Albuquerque, New Mexico</a>. North of Durango, 550 is nicknamed the <a href="/wiki/Million_Dollar_Highway" title="Million Dollar Highway" class="mw-redirect">Million Dollar Highway</a>.</p>
<p>Durango is served by a major regional airport for southwestern Colorado °™ Durango-La Plata Regional Airport (actually located near Ignacio). <a href="/wiki/Durango-La_Plata_County_Airport" title="Durango-La Plata County Airport" class="mw-redirect">Durango-La Plata County Airport</a> is serviced by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frontier_Express/Lynx_Aviation_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frontier Express/Lynx Aviation (United States) (page does not exist)">Lynx Aviation</a> (<a href="/wiki/Frontier_Airlines" title="Frontier Airlines">Frontier Airlines</a>), <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Express/SkyWest&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Express/SkyWest (page does not exist)">United Express/SkyWest</a> (<a href="/wiki/United_Airlines" title="United Airlines">United Airlines</a>), <a href="/w/index.php?title=US_Airways_Express/Mesa_Air&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="US Airways Express/Mesa Air (page does not exist)">US Airways Express/Mesa Air</a> (<a href="/wiki/US_Airways" title="US Airways">US Airways</a>), and <a href="/wiki/American_Eagle_Airlines" title="American Eagle Airlines">American Eagle</a> (<a href="/wiki/American_Airlines" title="American Airlines">American Airlines</a>).</p>
<p><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.durangogov.org/index.aspx?NID=333">Durango Transit</a> provides several bus routes that serve the community, including Fort Lewis College. Ignacio Road Runner provides bus service to the nearby towns of Ignacio and Bayfield with four trips daily on weekdays and one on Saturdays. Both services share the new Durango Transit Center (opened August 2010) as a hub.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Business">Business</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Durango,_Colorado&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Business">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Durango has a regional shopping center (Durango Mall) as well as a <a href="/wiki/Wal-Mart" title="Wal-Mart" class="mw-redirect">Wal-Mart</a>, which is larger than the Durango Mall.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Colleges">Colleges</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Durango,_Colorado&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Colleges">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Fort_Lewis_College" title="Fort Lewis College">Fort Lewis College</a> is situated on a 500&#160;ft <a href="/wiki/Mesa" title="Mesa">mesa</a> (bluff) overlooking downtown Durango, and is accredited by the Higher Learning Commission of the <a href="/wiki/North_Central_Association_of_Colleges_and_Schools" title="North Central Association of Colleges and Schools">North Central Association of Colleges and Schools</a>.</li>
<li>Southwest Colorado Community College, a branch of <a href="/wiki/Pueblo_Community_College" title="Pueblo Community College">Pueblo Community College</a>, is located in the Central Business District, on Camino del Rio.</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Juan_Basin_Technical_College&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Juan Basin Technical College (page does not exist)">San Juan Basin Technical College</a>, located outside of <a href="/wiki/Cortez,_Colorado" title="Cortez, Colorado">Cortez, Colorado</a>, 45 miles away, offers EMT certification in Durango.</li>
</ul>
